author: Rollmottle
content:
Been trying to think of a way in to the question about what I did without being completely frustrating or giving a list of moves that don't mean anything outside of the context of being in my chair, hearing what and how I hear.

This process for this song is like any other...listen for what the song needs and act accordingly. That's the frustrating answer but it's also true. What did you do? "I mastered it." lol

But I know that's not what you're asking. For a track like this, I'm primarily focused on the vocal and how it's sitting and feeling. The vocal performance is incredibly dynamic and intimate. This one had some ringy stuff through 2.5k and in the upper mid range that I felt was detracting from the "fireside" intimacy. The goal was to take off some of the edge without stepping on the presence. That was a combo of RX and EQ. 

On this song, I did an analog pass because I am usually able to manage to get the balance of presence and de-edge I'm looking for very quickly. Since time was of the essence here, that was the move. Couple of moves on Equilibrium digitally before the Gyraf and Porter Grinder in the analog chain. The "trickiest" thing I did here was flip the Porter Grinder into M/S to bring the vocal closer into the center (by cutting!) and to push the mellotron and atmospherics to the sides (by boosting). All very subtle stuff.

So, there were some moves here, but the moves were all in service of the feeling the song was telling me it needed. We talk a lot about monitoring here. When you can connect to the song and walk around inside of it, it's much easier to know what you need to do (or not to do) to bring it to life.

author: markmaclure
content:
You can read the patent for IRC here :https://patents.google.com/patent/US9225310B1/en?oq=Audio+limiter+system+and+method+izotope+US9225310B1
Basically the signal is processed multiple times with different attack and release times, then compared to the original signal. Each attack/release time is given a distortion and masking score and the best score is selected. The different IRC modes prioritize different types of scores (eg. IRC I prioritizes low pumping and distortion, IRC II is similar to IRC I but prioritizes transients more, etc). 
Izotope is a little cagey on the exact process they use to arrive at each IRC mode, but the manual does a pretty good job of explaining how each mode feels. IRC IV Transient is basically a multiband version of the other IRC modes that prioritizes transients, although Izotope says IRC V is its first multiband limiter in Ozone, so there is maybe more to the story there

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Hey @Gerhard Westphalen I don’t have time to read the replies so a quick summary of how I do it, sorry if it’s repeating 

1) Don’t take the limiter off, on many modern projects the music will be unrecognizable without it and it's what the artist approved. I typically reduce the limiting amount around 2dB, sometimes more sometimes less. I’ll also re balance clipper and limiter relationships

2) Don’t do any pre-emptive processing with the exceptions perhaps of paying a little extra care if it’s a project with heavy sibilance. Don’t mono the bass, don’t change the EQ etc 

3) Make a single WAV file of each side, and a set of timing notes that show where each track starts and the length so the cutting engineer can place the track banding / markers

4) I like to highlight anomalies that may present a challenge for cutter but it’s not necessary

author: hebakadry
content: Hey, pretty stoked about this new plugin.  Safe to say there hasn’t been much innovation in the lathe world until this plugin came around…was checking it out a bit in the beta testing phase…for those who aren’t cutting engineers the reference edition is absolutely amazing.  You can get a general sense of how your master will sound to cut and even audition various turntables and cartridges to see how it could sound.  Better language and tools when you’re communicating with your cutting engineer as well.  It also has an amazing visual emulation so you can actually see what’s going on with your grooves.  This is such a special plugin…i don’t get behind a lot of stuff but this is pretty game changing, esp for mastering engineers that don’t cut but actually care about the translation to LP. It was developed with Helmut Erler who was at Dubplates for many years…really amazing dude and friend of mine.  He's cut some really important techno records.  I think the visualization of the cutter head and the grooves will start to make sense to a lot of people that are a bit in the dark about cutting and modulation and how program material can really affect how things sound ultimately…also how you process your master esp when it goes to plants that do in house cuts that are a bit on the safe/boring side.  You can get ahead and provide a master that counteracts some of the wide processing moves they make to avoid distortion at all cost.  Also send your client a ref of what your cut could sound esp when people push back on super long programs that don't translate well https://www.tokyodawn.net/tdr-simulathe-ref/

author: chrissorem
content: I’ve been mastering a lot more of my own mixes recently. Mostly because I’m mixing into a mastering chain and generally doing very small moves. So my approach has been to take all my mixes and bypass the limiter and  load the sequence up. I’ll also have my limited mixes below my unlimited mixes in this session. Most the work I’m doing is light rx work and a touch of eq but mostly trying various limiters and limiter settings to see if I can beat what I did in the mix. The real advantage of mastering my own mixes is that once I move heard them in the final sequence I’ll sometimes adjust minor things in the mix. Maybe vocal up or bass down ect.. rather than trying to solve this with 2bus processing. The down side of me mastering is not getting a trusted second perspective

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I've definitely run into this sometimes. You have a lot of experience making records so I trust your read that it needs some. Sometimes I think on here, specifically, there is an almost -- too -- heavy focus on being minimal. Not to be critical, just to say that sometimes things need to be pulled far to make it more compelling. Sometimes things need A LOT. And your gut tells you that. Can't be afraid for people to tell you did too much, if you are truly just trying to connect with the song.

Even great mixes sometimes, from great mixers, need to be pulled far on occasion. And -- sometimes great mixes can actually take MORE. 

Band specific upward expansion to shape groove, master rebalance, heavy band specific satuaration to make things pop in a different way, I've done it all. Last week I had a master with CGII, 3 instances of Weiss DS-1 doing compression, expansion, de-essing, Spectre. Even Gold Clip. Which is rare, but if it needs it it needs it. 

Introduce contrasts if needed.

Just be unafraid, and love it (I know you will). There are no rules. Lean the fuck in!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
For real the first week in my new room I felt so drowsy that I kept falling asleep, like making EQ moves with my eyes closing by themselves. 

I thought I was just adjusting to the lack of light in the new windowless room, but turns out the fresh air system had been switched off the whole time and I was just slowly suffocating.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Just for reference, the convo was to restrict my approach to one band of EQ, Q of no sharper than .7 and maybe a low shelf. That's it. And a limiter.

Since then I've done at least over 100 songs, many of which are out in the world and/or on their way to release. So a decent time to circle back with some insight. However, compared to more experienced ears on here I am still a baby.

Extremely powerful challenge from Ruairi, and it really made me think in broad terms about what EQ is doing, what my goals are when using it, and how each part relates to another. And what you gain or lose when making a move. I would highly recommend it, and found it very very hard. It's non-trivial to make things sound better when you actually hear what's happening.

 I've also been pretty lucky to work on quite a bit of music that I would have considered outside of my experience range, and I think this gentler approach worked well there because the mixes were already pretty damn good. So there's that too!

Of course for work where I'm being paid I'm not only restricting to one band, I do whatever is needed but even so many times I would prefer that. It felt like "learning scales" but for mastering in a way. And loudness really is down mostly to EQ, as far as I can tell!

author: Nick Stetina
content:
Right. That ended up being my approach, not taking it as a prescriptive EQ order but just sussing out from that what they were trying to achieve.

A .1db tilt shelf and a few EQ moves no more than +/- .5db later and they “love it”. It was honestly a coin toss to me if they were going to reply that they couldn’t hear a difference, ha. Maybe that scratched their itch to have *some* input? 

In any case, they’re happy and I think not jumping into an even tactful version of “alright what’s really going on here” helped preserved the ‘experience’ a bit. When the customer sends their steak back the first time, serve up a new one to their liking right away. If they send it back again…maybe it’s okay for the chef to walk out and (politely) see wtf is going on 👨🏻‍🍳

author: Théo Quayle
content: Early days. I had printed then sent an album on its way to vinyl without listening through it first. This project had several seamless transitions, and I had printed everything without plugin latency compensation, which effectively gave every track about 200ms of silence at the end. Seamless transitions ruined. Thankfully it was caught in the test pressing and I owned up immediately, fixed the files, and insisted on paying the additional costs to get a new test. Release dates had to be pushed back, but at least I had cared enough to correct my mistake. Lessons learned. Could’ve been much worse

author: Rollmottle
content:
nah, fuck -1 or -2. theoretically the lower the ceiling, the less risk there is of intersample peaks happening upon conversion to MP3 or some other lossless format streamers use to stream audio to your device. even if there are ISP's, they usually light up a meter but are inaudible. i live at -0.5db for most everything. sometimes i'll go to -0.3db if it's something that is pop oriented (this is where i landed for @thejadenmejia's single for example). i think a lot of the panic about it is overblown. in the real world, clients like their shit loud.

as far as distro goes, i know some are starting to accept higher res files or even accepting multiple files. my deliverables have always been 96/24 and 44/16. I've recently started including 44/24's. i've always discouraged submitting anything other than 44/16 because who knows what some of these services are doing with SRC and dither, but i think with the advent of high res and lossless delivery, you are well-advised to submit the higher bit-rate files nowadays. all that said, with something like 44/24 you are probably pretty safe from getting your shit munched down-funnel.

author: Gerhard Westphalen

Well it depends. There’s a big difference between a file with a limiter vs no limiter and “here’s the file with my 10 mix bus plugins turned off”
Too many people are led to believe they need to turn everything off and then you’re stuck with half a mix or lim ref. If all you’re bypassing is a little limiting then yeah, no need to work off of the lim ref

author: Paris Lee
content:
Very exciting happenings…
Currently amazed at how the ADI does what it claims re: auto sensing balanced or unbalanced loads (dictating how it adjusts the internal impedance) , and giving the same sonic result either way. An amazing time today putting my Balanced MEA 2 on insert 1, then running into my Bal/Unbal Frank Lacy HPF to the Lacy Porter on insert 2. The original setup includes a way to balance the signal back before the A/D, and i have that, but it’s an extra piece of equipment that i never need/use. This was the feature that drew me to the ADI to be honest and made me pull the trigger…so does the ADI perform as it should…? Damn effing straight it does. What a box!!!! Nothing in, balanced signal…great…both eq’s in…no timbral change…either eq in by itself…no timbral change (other than what the boxes themselves would impart…but being a passive switcher and these boxes being what they are…and this converter what it is…there’s not a obtrusive timbral change imparted). 

Balanced…unbalanced…zero fucks given…what a box!

author: Edsel Holden
content:
I will share words that are not mine (these words belong to @Nomograph Mastering )

Context is important here. This is an email that Nomogrpah wrote back to a client that said "Hey I love the master so much but I am a bit worried about how much it might get turned down ?" or something to that effect 

Response was 

"Glad you are feeling the master!

Re the level thing that is a complicated question. A few thoughts

Not everyone has loudness normalization turned on. It also doesn’t exist on Smart TVs, many streaming web interfaces etc

The different services all have different level norm targets (and even different settings within just Spotify) - and they change pretty regularly

In terms of absolute level when normalization is active what matters is arrangement (dense mixes sound quieter than sparse/spacious mixes), EQ (bright/mid range forward mixes sound louder than dark) and distortion levels (clipped/distorted mixes feel perceptually louder than clean). If I make a master a dB louder in mastering using just limiting for example, they just turn it down a dB more when it’s level normed.

So what does all of this mean? It means that every song has sweet spot where the EQ/tone, the arrangement and the overall clipping/limiting level works best and communicates the intent. That’s what we aim for.

You can use a site like loudnesspenalty.com to see what will happen but it will just drive you crazy and the only real way to meaningfully alter the result is to change the arrangement/mix or overall EQ a lot. On release day you can find 1000 records that are louder than yours if you want to.

If being the loudest is the intent - game everything listed above and you can “win”. If doing your unique thing and communicating a song and a performance is the goal then I think you are there!"

(posted with Nomographs permission)

author: Rollmottle
content:
1. Pull in all pre-masters into one session. Name all regions and order it as intended. 
2. Initial pre-master listen to gain the material to be generally the same RMS (material dependent of course) so that it hits my analog chain at a consistent level....draw in any obviously needed volume automation. 
3. Start mastering....which for me is two steps...the actual deep pre-master listen to understand what the track may need. It is as this stage where I'll address any technical issues (pre-analog processing, RX work, additional automation refinement, etc.). Then comes the actual master processing step and the subsequent master capture.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I appreciate that and hope you know how much you’re appreciated on here. There is so little info on actually, truly mastering out there. And how to carve your own path in it considering the skills and trade offs needed to find your own way. You challenging us with questions lets us consider where we stand and learn.

This is probably a deeper discussion, but I do think it’s “easy” to get distracted going deep on technical stuff rather than learning the rock solid fundamentals of listening for intention, EQ, etc. In a way you can trick yourself into thinking you are learning something relevant when you are just procrastinating (at least I’ve noticed this in myself).

To tie back to sample rates/earlier discussion…my use of EQ is a much bigger barrier to getting better masters than my sample rate algorithm. For you the sample rate conversion algo may be the difference to get that extra 2%. 

That’s not to say the sample rate stuff doesn’t matter, but as you said, it’s important to understand where we all are at, where our time is best spent, and when to utilize or worry about certain things!!

Will be back next week would love to go deeper on some of this!

author: Slow Hand

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I immediately change the frequency graph to *Log* or *Extended Log*. This allows me to see the low-end and midrange with more resolution. It's the same reason most EQ graphs keep the octaves evenly spaced so that 50% of your freq graph isn't 10kHz and up. It gives you more resolution for the notes in the lower octaves.

As for FFT size or window shape, I never change it, but as Ruairi alluded to it requires an understanding of the physical limitations of FFT's. 

In short if you want very fine frequency information displayed you can change the window size and lose rhythmic information. But it you want very precise rhythmic visualization you have to sacrifice how much frequency information the FFT can display. So the ideal setting ultimately depends on what problem you're trying to solve.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Keep in mind I’m still very new to mastering compared to most here, but this has happened several times already to me.

I’d do it on goodwill. Ideally your workflow and back end systems would make this a very small lift. Unless it’s something wild, better to have the client have a wonderful experience, keep their momentum, don’t introduce doubt, double down on their confidence, etc.

I’m assuming it would be something like making sure the levels and overall tone are right if you’ve already mastered them all and they are in the same ballpark, but feel free to tell me if I’m wrong.

Also “cohesion” is massively overrated to me anyway, I much prefer a creatively interesting and varied listening experience if the music calls for it as long as we are not having wild level or EQ swings or something (sometimes it calls for cohesion to have the best listening experience IMO, so know that too!). 

I’ve had multiple instances where an artist’s new “single” release includes their several past singles I’ve mastered too. They didn’t tell me they were doing that, and I mastered each totally alone, just based on the song and their vision. And to be honest those collections sounded totally fine every time as a group of singles, mastered alone.

All that said, I’d definitely politely educate them on what it exactly entails so it doesn’t happen again in future, and so they can take it into account creatively.

But of course where you are in your career, the relationship with this client, etc all plays into this. Someone like @Nomograph Mastering could very well see this very differently than me

author: Ross Fortune
content:
On that note, can't remember where I found this but a related piano recipe from Michael Brauer. Hoping he hasn't trademarked this one so the Discord doesn't get shut down.



"Remember the early Elton John records? Remember how his piano shimmered? At mediasound we loved that sound so a lot of us were always playing around with getting different versions of it. No lacquered hammers, no Dolby A off, just a combination of compression and EQ.


I only recorded Luther's voice, may he rest in peace, on that song along with "searching" and then mixed both. Luther was on a whole other level of singers. He walked into that session and listened to the song in the control room once, then he walked out into the studio with the lyric sheet in his hand. What you hear on"Glow of Love" and "searching" is his first fun down reading the lyrics from a yellow pad. No punches.


The piano sound you’re referring to is probably the same one that I did for Vandross on the “Never too much” song.


Ok, this is how you do it.

1. First insert an LA3A or LA2A (depending on the version of sound you’re going after) across the stereo piano tracks. The LA2A is good if the song is slow and the chords are quarter notes. The LA3A is good if the chords are faster with a harder attack like in “never too much”. Bang those meters and 
2. out of the compressor go into a couple of pultecs and push up..way up the 3 or 5 k on the low end and the 8 or 10 k on the high end. Don’t be safe. 
3. Now go to the desk EQ and start clearing out some of the muddiness and EQ up the remaining mids so that it just shimmers like a baby. 
4. When it’s done right, you can hear the harmonics riding up during each sustain.  
5. I remember hearing that song on the radio and man that piano was making me feel good all over. Sounds pretty simple when you know how to do it right?”

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my understanding (and please correct me if I'm wrong), what I've seen and tried De-Clip on is audio that is already clipped and distorted. In this case, speeding up the master before dither just introduced actual sample peaks in a 32bit file, which can represent them. So there wasn't any "clipping" going on, it was just a matter of...how do we get the file to a similar loudness at 24bit to deliver without it sounding awful? I suppose you could try the de-clip after limiting (which was introducing distortion).

But...a legendary human who doesn't want to be known as the speed up guy  helped me out with some sorcery, so it's solved (and honestly I know sorta what was happending but have no clue how he actually did it)

AND the artist is super pumped, loves the new version so it's a win

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Howdy folks! Started running some tests for the tiktok normalisation but I've found an engineer that's already run some tests and discovered a fair bit.

Quick notes:
Web tiktok and mobile tiktok process audio differently: 
- Web tiktok has a -1db ceiling. 
- Mobile tiktok compress the audio. This engineer reckons its a soft knee comp at -12, 50.1 ratio, fast attack.

I'm still running some loudness tests. Heavy compression at -12 seems a little too murderous to me.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
In modern record making clipping and limiting on the buss is a huge part of the overall sound and feel of a record. Kendrick for example never heard his productions, mixes or masters without it. Clipping has an energy in the kicks and snares that was built a certain way, limiting has rounding and smoothing characteristics and often "holds" the track in a particular way. You can't just bypass one , or the other or both without huge changes in groove, balance, tone and feel. (Swapping limiters for something *safer* can be equally damaging) 

What does clipping actually do? It creates square waves at the extreme (for the duration of the clipping)

What is a square wave? It is a fundamental with a bunch of odd harmonics trailing off in level

What happens when you low pass the square wave at the converter reconstruction filter, lathe low pass etc? It is no longer a square wave

Does cutting this no longer square wave to a disc for brief periods present challenges and cause extra momentary distortion? Yes

Is that trade off worth while? I believe so and have itterated on this belief across hundreds and hundreds of projects cut and pressed to vinyl and then compared carefully with the original digital files

author: Rollmottle
content:
I’ve found it easier to separate the tonal decisions from loudness decisions. I take the limiter out of the equation when I am making tonal decisions. So in my case, it's a simple bypass of with processing vs. without to make the decisions against the mix. This is inherently level matched. This gets trickier with dynamics processing but that’s a simple offset of the processed mix. That’s all happening on the object in my DAW without need for additional plugins or routing. Since I am rarely compressing anyways, this is a low friction way of judging the moves against the mix. 

When I’m happy with that, I’ll print the pre-lim and then load it up on another track to do the limiting. When I’m happy with the limiting, I have a quick action to create an A/B track where I can load the hot mix or mix to see if I’m as loud or louder than it. 

None of this is by number or meter. It’s all by ear.

author: Øra Mastering
content:
I always end up chasing my tail when separating tonal and loudness. If I get the right tonal balance first, then everything shifts around when adding loudness/limiting. To me all limiters and limiter styles within have different tones, at least if I’m limiting more then a couple of dB. For that reason I always start with finding the right limiter/style that keeps or changes the tonal balance the way I want (too bright mix = dark limiter, dull mix = bright limiter, great mix = limiter that keeps the balance when pushed ect.). Once I have the loudness and given the tonal balance a gentle push in the right direction with the limiter, I get the track over the finish line with eq or other tools in front of the limiter. 

This is not meant as criticism of your approach, I just haven’t cracked that code.
Hats of to you for making that work!

author: masteredbyjack
content:
In my experience (again, caveated by it being rather limited compared to some on here), a gentle shelf wins most of the time.

This isn’t quite like soothe, but I’ve found success in certain situations using the weiss ds1-mk3 in the low pass mode, so it is only working on the area below the filter (as I understand it, and it appears to me). This seems to my ears to not have the bad multiband smearing problems of say fabfilter mb, etc

In situations where the dynamics down there are out of whack and you need to control the groove better it can really work great, but that specific plugin has odd release characteristics that take time to understand. That same flexibility can allow some subtle control down there that can actually accentuate the groove and fix your problems at the same time.

As with everything, there are trade offs, it can make the low end sound odd if not careful, and you really need a room that is accurate down there to judge it well I think (now that I’m in my current setup I can very clearly hear when it is helping or hurting)

author: Adam Thein
content: For RX standalone, I usually like to set my frequency scale to Linear when I'm looking for clicks which visualize a lot of the time like a tall line extending across the entire frequency spectrum like in this example on a bass with a bad edit.  You can also see them in a traditional waveform with the weird hard lines between samples.  You can try editing them out with Mouth Declick, Declick, or manually with Spectral Repair tools (either attenuation or replace algorithms) or interpolation.  Or you can manually try and delete a few samples in the wave form to re-build the waveform where the samples would be more naturally smooth.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
What comes to mind quickly is:

1. Listen to the file after the export from master session (many of us do this in RX)

2. Consider what deliverable is needed (default for me is to deliver sample rate of what it came in at, 24 bit).

3. Consider how high your output ceiling should be based on the type of arrangement, etc. True Peak could play a role in this depending on the type of record

4. If there are alts, make sure they are aligned and exactly the same length as the main mix (again easy to check length in RX)

5. If you are doing SRC (say they need a 48k and 44k 16bit deliverable) check the SRC file as well to ensure that the SRC did not introduce any overs — it will quantize them to zero if you dither after but best to check still

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Hey folks! Following on from this, had a bit of time today to do some more testing, I've done a pink noise test today. 1 track 3 different loudnesses 5db apart. Uploaded the different loudnesses separately too.

Finds: (please note this is off of web TikTok, app TikTok tests will come soon)
• -4.6db overall (planning on testing this more in depth, but occurred 4 times on the 4 different audios I uploaded)
• Int LUFS -7.4 down to -13.3 (for this specific case).
• 5db differences remain.
• Brickwall eq at 16khz (this was tested on many different videos).
• The different levels uploaded separately did not change their respective loudnesses compared to the full noise track. So dynamic sections of track shouldn't boost if uploaded as a separate sound to TikTok.
• No compression.
• General audio quality does drop.

Things that come to mind:
•  Common 3rd party video editing apps (such as capcut) and how they affect audio
• The level control TikTok users have and how that affects audio (in terms of peak/loudness and referring back to the -4.6db peak mentioned earlier)


I'll run some more tests when I get the time to.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
My guess (and it’s a guess I don’t use sequoia) is that Em is “clipping” by using 32 or 64 bit in the DAW (what they all run at) — when you print at 24 or 16bit it will quantize away the overs (so any sample over 0 goes to 0).

Shockingly you can actually clip off a lot of level this way (I dislike the sound and would always choose to use a limiter but from what I’ve seen it doesn’t sound like awful digital clipping)

An issue I’ve run into often enough to care — when people take off a limiter but print at 24 bit and there are samples at 0 — they are going over since the plugins on the mix bus have internal headroom — I once had a bud taking off 6db this way (unintentionally) on the non-lim prints and it actually sounded okay (not good or recommended, but okay)

Of course on our end we cannot tell if the non-lim with samples at 0 is actually this (it could be a clipper, whatever) without knowing the mixer and asking.

The solve is to print non-lim at 32bit float but that’s not always possible (and if the mix is not hot going into the final limiter with over 0s it doesn’t really matter)

If I’m wrong on any of this someone please correct

author: Øra Mastering
content:
That makes sense, thanks for the explanation. Reading this, I don’t think we’re miles appart. I used to have one «default» limiter and focus all my moves in front of that, also adding limiter/loudness as the last step. When doing so, I always found myself having to tweak the moves (that I already had «perfectly» dialed in) because everything would change when adding the final limiter. That’s when I would be chasing my tail 😅
Now I start with getting the limiter right for the song and then doing eq moves as the second step. This way it it a lot less back and forth for me. I should say I only use one limiter at the time and the limiters I audition with are dmg limitless, fabfilter pro-l2 and Ozone maximizer, with styles I know well. Dmg usually gets used on acoustic and jazz, pro-l2 & ozone for pop/rock. If it is music with vocals I find different styles can really change the way the vocals are percieved, so it’s mostly chosing the style that support the vocals best that is the goal. Using two minuttes to get the right limiter from the start saves me time and uncertainty down the road, and in some cases let’s me use less eq to get the desired result.
There are many roads to Rome as they say, I was just interested in yours bc whenever I tried that it ended in a lot of second guessing (for me!). 

Do you find yourself having to add more eq when adding limiter at the end to keep the tonal balance you have acheived?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hey. There’s nothing wrong with putting EQs and limiters on your master buss as you mix. A little bit of EQ or a lot of limiter is alright.

The answer here is to mix *into* your limiter. You don’t want to mix the entire song and then slap a limiter on at the end for loudness. As you’ve discovered that will mess up the balances that you’ve spent so much time getting right. You want to ease the final limiting in as you’re building the mix.

I usually start a mix by pulling my limiter down a few dB. Enough to get everything starting to touch the limiter. To get the loudness in the ballpark.

Then I’ll push into it a little more so that I’m starting to get some gain reduction. Certain instruments may begin to get pushed down or distorted in a way I don’t like. Maybe the kick is hitting the limiter too hard, so I bring it’s level down and then lower my limiter some more.

Continue this process of adjusting balances into your limiter as you mix until you’ve got the loudness where you want it. Usually I’m checking in on my limiter a few times throughout the mix to see if I can push it harder without penalty. When I hear it distort in a way that I don’t like I back off.

Hope that helps some.

author: spectrummasters
content:
...so, the short answer jack is yes , the wide q eq moves are definitely advantageous and applicable outside of the mastering stage (for my workflow)....very much so. I think in a way , the broad eq is sort of like a painter taking a few steps back from the canvas having been working up close on a detailed brushstroke (which I’d suggest for example is like a surgical eq move in a mix or saturating a sound at the production stage etc).....”stepping back” and listening not just to The minutiae but the overall tone i think is a discipline that is potentially easy to forget in mix mode ......and in a sense this is how the broad EQ is serving me . I find the eq points ruairi shared work v well at the group bus stage also......for light touches

With regards to whether I’m only mastering . No, currently my most common paid work comes from local / independent artists in my network I’ve built mostly from my local community outwards through word of mouth. This is primarily in the rnb/trap/hip-hop genres and for better or worse it appears to have been normalised that when someone wants a mix....what they want is a mixter. I’m with Derek Ali’s Enginears platform and even there they are promoting a free master from us as mixers on the platform.
Personally, I’m not against certain mixers mastering as well....but i think this is more genre specific.....and also v much down to the individual. I think you spoke about your arc on here into mastering and others have too. ....i believe there is much to benefit from having professional mastering engineers, with thousands of hours under their belt listening to thousands of tracks in excellent environments......take the final listen and make the final adjustments on a mix..and for me, i consider myself on a career arc towards becoming that .

author: Iwan Morgan
content:
Interesting response by Chris Gehringer in the new MWTM Q+A section: 

*"Dereck, You really hit home with this one.
I’m 99% ITB for over 10 years was well. I was more hybrid earlier on during my conversion period and now mostly all in due to my workflow and client time demands.

I definitely feel like i’m chasing Refs with the same plugins used by mixers and producers sometimes and don’t feel creative but that’s the game lately. I really feel this is the main problem. I’m not really happy when i’m pushed in that direction.
With almost everyone having the same plugins it’s very apparent that most masters in a shootout sound the same now. No surprises there.

Is Analog Better?

I recently bought a Terry Audio CEQ to try and change my sound and it definitely works. It has an amazing sound and color that cannot be found in most plugins. That being said it doesn’t work for me all the time.
Many of the projects i work on are so loud and pushed anything run through analog gear loses the “glue” that is in the digital mix.
I also just got a Sontec MES-432D9D from Make Believe Studios.
It actually sounds like the real thing to me. It has a much different vibe when using it. I find myself using different frequencies from other EQs.
Is That Better? I’m not sure yet but getting good results when i use both of these tools.

I think the most important part of my setup is that I’m very familiar with my plugins and know when to use different ones when necessary (its also so easier to try another one if you’re not sure obviously)
I’m constantly trying to stay fresh and not mail it in.

Not sure if there’s an actual answer for this but i hope i answered some of your question or at least validated our situation.

Chris"*

author: jordanmcleod_io
content: I'm no where as experienced as some of the other peeps in here, but have some thoughts. I think you kind of answered your own questions. $10 is crazy low and not sustainable for anyone, I'm not sure what that other engineer could actually be doing besides blasting tracks through Ozone. Since you are already cold emailing, I think your time could be better sent searching out artists who are in need of an ME and get your full rate there. If you took the $10/gigs, they would eventually be dropped anyways as more full rate gigs started coming in. If it were me, I would rather work the word of mouth game through the artists you are DMing and hopefully more gigs stream in that way via other artists, producers, or mixers. Put in the work now creating meaningful relationships and connections that can exponentially grow instead of the label path which seems like a dead end. I've been cold DMing artists with a freebie first song, I just started this month and it's a big numbers game, so I can't say for certain how it will go. But, because of the freebie I gave them, I am now talking with these different artists about mastering an album, an EP, and several singles at full rate. This is rhetorical, but how many cheap label songs would you need to master in order to get the same amount of money? So in short, if it were me, I would spend my time elsewhere creating more meaningful relationships with much more room to grow.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my side I always want to keep working with people -- you never know how the relationships evolve (I know you know this, you are more experienced than me). I just tackle the notes -- it's rare I would ever say it wasn't a great experience. I want to master as many records as I can. At the very most I would let them come back again, say it's not the right fit and suggest someone I know to be a good fit (I've done this before). But always with the art and their vision first, if I truly don't understand it.

That said -- I did get really close to walking on a recent project, we were way down a rabbit hole, I think I legitimately did 15 masters. And we were caught up on dither, comparing to pink noise, etc. It was wild. We got it across the line - but I went way out of what would be constituted by us as what the "mastering role" should say, because the music was great and I thought the artist could understand my perspective. And I think it actually hit, to refocus on the art and feeling. 

It's a fine line. Sometimes I get the impression that I do step out of what is supposed to be said by mastering engineers -- but people seem to connect with that on my side. 

Also if things are going that way I will just stream it to them -- often they are looking for control or are having a hard time making decisions -- something I see in this new crop of record makers who only have ever worked in a DAW. Hard to know without actually knowing the humans

Then again, many many times I get a note and it's great and insightful and I love it

author: Rollmottle
content:
The Massive Passive is a beautiful EQ and does "the thing" exceptionally well...it's just not as versatile as I've come to need out of a box if I'm going out because it has inherent trade-offs that make it only partially useful when its in the signal path. I found myself only ever consistently using the top 2 bands because of the low-end mushiness. When I'm talking low-end mushiness, we are talking really subtle shades of gray, but at this stage can really make or break how a master hits, especially when thumpy kick drums are so critical to almost everything. It works a treat on drumless/acoustically oriented stuff, but that's more the exception of what flows across my desk than the rule. 

What I moved on to from the MP (the Gyraf G14S) gives me what I want when I'm going out without the inherent trade off in the low end. The ability to use it in either solid state or tube topology made it a no-brainer for me. It just does "the thing" cleaner and better than the MP. Where the MP is rich and dark, the Gyraf is rich and cleaner. I think at the end of the day, "tube" wasn't the thing I was looking for.

author: Rollmottle
content:
The things to check vary based on the requested deliverables. If you’re not really doing this regularly, for you, I'd make sure you’re asking up front if there are alts or files for physical releases that you need to account for. Cleans, instrumentals, acapellas, sequence, overlapping crossfades, metadata, PQ sheets, less lims, vinyl, etc. all may start to matter to finalizing something. And if you haven’t accounted for the deliverable and the time it takes to prep and QC in your rates, well you may be in for some pain.

Others may have some of these steps in different spots, but for me, it's roughly:

1. Print approved masters at native sample rate and bit depth.
1a. < Deprecate un-used versions>
1b.  <SRC/dither to any other sample rates and bit depth requested>
1c. <Assemble any physical deliverables>
2. Listen to every single file you’ve printed & check any data
3. Deliver

I did this recently for a rush master that had no time to go back to mix, reverb tail on the vocal cut off after a measure of the last note.

I stemmed out the vocal in RX, brought it back in to WAVELAB, full wet on vintage verb EQ and time until it sounded close to what i was hearing on the MST, and then mixed it down to the right level in parallel to the mix.. had my final limiter on the “output” summing bus of wavelab.

Worked great and no one knew the wiser.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
So, in most cases, you can go over 0 dB in your DAW if you're working in 32-bit (or higher) precision, and you won’t necessarily hear the clipping. This is because the internal audio engine can handle peaks above 0 without immediate distortion—it’s all about floating-point processing magic.

Now, whether the audio gets normalized to stay under 0 dB depends on what happens during export. Sometimes, what you're seeing in the DAW or Ozone meters isn’t exactly what ends up in the final file—especially if there's a limiter, normalization, or post-processing involved. It’s even possible that the version you’re analyzing wasn’t actually the one that was officially released. Happens more often than you’d think!

That said, it’s not unusual to see mixes or masters that are technically clipping more so going over 0... in tools like Ozone or the DAW but sound fine due to the flexibility of floating-point processing. I’m not saying this is a best practice—but I’ve definitely played around with it. I’ve even intentionally clipped files way past 0 dB, re-exported them, and compared them to cleaner versions. They sounded different, but at that point, I found myself asking, “Why am I trying to squeeze one more dB of loudness out of something that’s already crushed and competitive?” Classic overthinking, right?

Anyway, back to your question: I think what you’re seeing is a product of the DAW working internally at 32- or 64-bit, so it can handle those overs without clipping during processing. Then, during export, maybe they normalized it, maybe they fixed it later, maybe it did just didn't sound distroted haha... or maybe that’s just not the real released version at all. Who knows?  I would not lose sleep over it and also know what you have seen is not a "secret" that your missing haha.

author: Ted Whitten Media
content: Yeah they're just using peak/RMS on the metering section, the k system has colored ranges on it. So that's actually going out of Ozone like that. But as mentioned before, it's floating point, so no worries there. There's got to be some gain staging after that, 5 db of steady clipping would sound like it's being run through a fuzz pedal. Lol.

author: Paris Lee
content:
@Stefan Hi Stephen, this is a great question! 
There are two issues at play here: One the more obvious, sending the signal to multiple A/D’s, and then, maybe a little less obvious: the issue of how your system is being clocked, and whether the A/D you’re auditioning is exerting maximum performance based on these conditions. Personally, to feed multiple converters, I use a Maselec MTC 1x console. This offers two identical outputs. So the analog signal part of that is solved right there. There are other ways to address this problem like outboard switchers. 

But here’s the real problem, clocking. *Generally*, and when i say generally probably in almost 100 percent of cases, the A/D converter sounds its best when it is the master clock of your system. Of course there are *certain* converters that *may* benefit from external clocking, but I’m not jumping into that can of worms. You can read ENDLESS arguments on Gearspace about this. 

I’ll say up front that I think clock sounds best just getting transferred straight through the AES audio feed to your interface, vs using a BNC output to your system, but again, I could get pushback there, that’s my opinion. 

So- let’s get to it, you have two A/D’s running AES feeds into your interface. Now, on your interface itself- you need to choose what AES feed your choosing to Sync to- so you’re going to choose one aes feed, or the other. This doesn’t *preclude you* from solo’ing each feed in your DAW. But the main thing here is that when you audition one converter, you need to also go to your control panel of your interface and select that AES feed to sync if you really want to hear the correct sound. 

In sum, I would do it this way and record a 30-45 pass of each. Then audition them that way (i use comp lanes on the same track to achieve this).

Another possible way to do this is having an outboard aes switcher like a z sys and switching the converters to the same aes output. Hope this helps!

author: Calvin Lauber
content:
Hey guys- so I’m asking this question I guess in a mixing context but I know it’s a common function of mastering so I thought I’d post here. 

I always have an instance of ozone maximizer at the end of my chain that I mix into. I’m generally happy with the results/loudness I get and comfortable with the parameters, except I never really mess with the “character” which I suppose is the speed/release of the limiting? 

On a recent mix I slowed it down more than I ever would, which really just means making it slower at all from the defaul setting, I usually stick very close to it, and I really like how it made the pocket of my mix feel. But I guess, I have always understood people to use very fast release compression on masterbusses.. 

do you all find yourselves moving the character/release of the final limiter around pretty widely to get the right feel or are you typically keeping it quite fast?

author: masteredbyjack
content: For ozone character is a combo of release/lookahead/etc

author: Moses Mastering
content: yes i will move attack and release all the time for every song depending on gear or plugin.. i actually think attack and release at mastering is kind of a make or break to a lot of my "sound"...... to dial in the groove of the song... also with that ozone  character slider if its fast it will have a tendency to distort if pushed hard. You can slow it down and get a cleaner sound ... and while you then lose a bit of volume you can then actually limit it more to make it back up. I notice when i move it to slow i lose about .2-.4 db in final level, so then I can gain it back up and take that "off" in the limiter. This might sound silly haha.. but it gets me the same "loudness" of the "loud" setting while being cleaner. Sometimes i just use loud though when it sounds right haha. this is not a perfect science but general observation and application haha.

author: miguel @ knurlmastering
content:
I try not to change the hardware from song to song. The chain I create for each record defines the sonic character of the entire project. If I need track-specific adjustments, I’ll add plugins before the hardware chain. That way, each song is shaped to fit the chain I designed for the record. After the hardware, I will add plugins as well, typically something like limiting.

In the end, every song is tweaked individually. Often there are plugins for specific sections, along with level automation within the track. Once those adjustments are made, all songs then run through the hardware chain.

I always print the hardware chain, so when revisions come up (making something a little louder or quieter, or adjusting a fade-in or fade-out) I don’t need to recall the hardware.

author: samvalentine

Hey yall - I'm looking to pick up a new limiter/clipper plugin... Think it's time a branch out from being an ozone boy. Thanks!

author: ehutton21
content:
i know people swear by the boz big clipper but there’s a lot of ways to clip. standard clip by SIR is really good for situations where i don’t need to control attack and release etc and i love using it on vocals because it’s really gentle on the voice, it adds this really nice saturation i don’t find elsewhere, and it discourages you from going over the top. 

If I’m fully honest I don’t think leaving ozone is gonna make a crazy difference, the IRC IV clipping mode is fairly malleable and i’ve found it more musical than everything else except Boz. Kazrog clipper is one that certain people swear by because it’s a multiband format, but its just a matter of preference. What don’t you like about ozone? That might be helpful knowledge in the process of suggesting where you go!

author: samvalentine
content:
Thanks man! So I do like ozone quite a bit actually. I'm not looking to totally replace it, but it's been my go to for years now and I think it's time I expanded my horizons... Add another tool or two to the arsenal you know.
How will you decide what limiter to use on a song? Is it kinda genre dependent or nothing that simple?

author: ehutton21
content:
comfort & best range of flexibility is my criteria. I prefer having attack and release controls and being able to tweak it all accordingly, and that’s why i’m keen on ozone and boz—ozone fits so seamlessly in with the rest of my bus compression as well. everyone does mix-bus differently and for me the biggest thing i want my clipper to do is to catch the peaks that my bus compressor hasn’t dealt with as in full and provide a little more “push” without squashing anything. for me, i try to keep mix bus processing pretty consistent in terms of tools but vary the control settings to match the song. pro-q (pulling down very subtle things i don’t want), bus compressor, my quick little ozone chain, and then the boz clipper.

it varies from genre to genre on occasion but most of the artists i work with have a very consistent “radio friendly” sound that’s kind of genre blending, so i get to work closely with them on determine the feel.

T-racks classic clipper does some stuff in the low-end. Can't remember it exactly but it's a little bump and a HP I believe (should do measurements again). Standardclip by SIR is my go to most of the time (and since I'm in FL i get to use the fruity soft clipper, which is "the secret" to that "FL studio sound" all these protools engineers keep talking about. They think it's the fruity limiter, but FL producers have moved on from that because it sounds really bad, everyone uses the soft clipper and it's amazing for hiphop drums.)
For limiters I use a few, sometimes combinations (using multiple limiters spreads the workload a bit). I love the ozone vintage limiter, but I always use it in very small amounts, barely any gr. Fabfilter L2 is popular for a reason, can't really go wrong with that one imo. Waves L1 can work sometimes, but i rarely use it on a mixbus. Weiss by softube is a cool collection, Newfangled Elevate is nice too.
Now that I think of it the Elysia alpha compressor also has a softclip function that I utilize sometimes.

author: Jodonny
content:
https://www.instagram.com/reel/Ci03PtygJmV/?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y=

Please let me know if I’m crazy - I’ve seen this guy refer to the sidechain filter in Pro-C as “compressing the midrange” as if it’s a multiband comp in multiple mastering videos I’ve come across. He says he likes to expand his highs and lows and compress mids. I’m just shocked that a successful engineer doesn’t understand that a Key just changes what frequencies trigger the entire full band compressor. Am I missing something here??

author: Jodonny
content: I also know he’ll use other plugins to expand the highs and lows and compress the mids, which makes me think he thinks the pro C is doing this

author: Jodonny
content: Yeah, I’d be curious to test it somehow. I guess setting the comp till it triggers from the midrange and then high passing it up to the hats would tell. If it’s still getting gain reduction then, then yeah I guess maybe the tops could trigger it?

author: Jodonny
content:
Haha, I don’t think anyone here is debating what the key filter is doing in the Pro-C. 

And that is not the same as using a multiband comp to compress just the mids. A comp with a key to trigger the compressor with just mids in there is still going to compress the bass frequencies and highs. It’s compressing the entire mix. A multiband would only compress the mids if setup that way.

author: peterlabberton
content:
@Nomograph Mastering we’ve had some discussions on here to this effect in the past, but I’m curious your perspective:

I’ve been sending out mixes over the last ~6 months that are only barely backed off my ref mixes for clients. Basically Pro-L2 is my final stage, and if it’s only grabbing a few dB on the ref mix, I might just send that off as is. Or if it’s ended up more aggressive I’ll pull it back and usually end up with it grabbing maybe ~3dB on loud drum hits, maybe more here and there. Essentially aiming to keep some of its effect on drum transients but leave the rest of the track alone. I’ve gotten no complaints from mastering folks and it seems like many mixers are doing this (?)… When you get mixes like this (assuming they’re good enough mixes), are you banging your head against the wall and significantly compromised in your work, or do you just get to work and master the record?

author: hebakadry
content: Very quick take on the vinyl gripes some people have.  I am of the younger cutting generation and I can definitely assure you guys that cutting engineers today are way better than the nostalgia people have about cutting “back in the day”.  We have amazing tools now…plugins to manually de-ess the program material cutting engineers get from mastering engineers that have had ZERO sibilance mitigation, totally blasted material at -6LUFS with clipped transient information, distortion, you name it….we actually have tools now to fix these issues that people 20 years ago had only one knob to process it.  We even had a tiny amount of innovation on pitch computers which were last made in the early 80s.  That being said..there has been very little innovation in lathes otherwise…we are still working with lathes from 1970 or earlier because literally NO ONE has been able to improve upon the sheer magnitude of incredible feat of engineering lathe machines that Neumann and Scully made 50 years ago.  There have been kickstarters…many many dudes tried, they literally all failed.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Linear phase is a made-up necessity by big plugin conglomerates. 

It’s potentially mathematically helpful for multi-mic sources, but in mastering, I don’t see a benefit. Even with multi-mic sources, I’m more apt to avoid HPF/LPF and opt for shelving/bells on a non-linear phase eq than reach for the linear phase tool. 

Also, nearly every bit of processing will affect the phase somehow. There’s no sense in being so precious with phase that we stop listening to tone.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
That's fantastic, @ALXCPH. My all-or-nothing hot take on linear phase was more in the spirit of “making assertions” (in Seth Godin’s terminology). 

Honestly, my caveat to my previous statement is that linear phase processing is likely operating in a lot of plugins behind the scenes. Many times when I'm using RX, I notice processes adding the pre or post ring of linear phase even if that's not an option I'm selecting.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’m potentially missing the point here (there are probably reasons you mastering lot stay in RX rather than Tools), but… could you apply the workflow I use for declicking audio in PT to what you’re looking for above?

Eg - lead vocal will almost certainly have some clicks. I duplicate playlist (with suffix _Dclk), open up RX DeClick in Audiosuite and set to stun. Render it on the whole playlist indiscriminately while reading LWMR discord.

Flip back to the main playlist. Listen through with an egregious high shelf and a boatload of compression - comp up from the _Dclk playlist whenever you hit a click. 

Maybe some combo of this idea with Batch processing in RX could speed things up?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
What @hyanrarvey and others said...but usually this is used to get a bounce with the compression to make sure it is releasing in time with the groove. In gridded stuff like hip-hop you can actually be really mathematic with it, but generally you don't need to it's about the feel. Of course every compressor is different even with the same "settings"...you can set the attack to let enough transient in and the release to basically make the compressor return to "zero" in time with the movement of the groove. But the release shape, etc will definitely play a role in this too

At least this is how I'm usually using it (though very rarely compressing at all, and when I do I'm using the Weiss DS1-Mk3 plug which has complicated release characteristics). Feel free to correct me if I'm off the mark on this! It is about feel and making the record pump in a pleasing way which can add energy. But of course it's helpful to be very specific about what part of the groove you're actually wanting to bring out (or back) so to me it's hugely about your gut reaction to how the groove moves you

author: Bonati12461
content: I use RX but discovered that the Spectrum view in Wavelab has coarser controls but I can work faster in-program rather than hopping to another app. Just set up a hotkey for the attenuation button (my default attenuation is -1dB) and then draw your little window around the offending area and tap tap tap that hotkey until you like the result. I’m pretty fast at this now - it’s my surgical de-ess technique but you can obv use it for everything else (rando resonate bass note, weird LF bumps, pesky guitar notes, etc etc).

author: hebakadry
content: Yeah definitely works in multi channel mode…you can use the spectral mode view to see all your files in your session on a spectral view and then the spectrum mouse tool to edit specific sections.  It’s def good for super quick cleanup when you don't want that choke.  I don’t normally work it in that way personally…I generally like to create an object for a section and then use the offline spectral repair to clean up the specific area because I just have more control in offline mode…also I can see where I did all my edits based on the splice if I need to repeat that on another version.  It’s not as deep as RX, but I still absolutely love it..so yeah great for efficiency.  I think I use it more than RX in a way because it all stays in the same environment and it’s super fast and easy.  You can still setup RX as an external tool in your object editor and stay in sequoia btw.  I have both RX and Spectralayers setup that way.  The only annoying thing is that you can’t have 2x ASIO running at the same instance which is very annoying. So I have to disable ASIO in my audio setup in Sequoia before I pull up RX..this is only if I want to STAY in the session.  Of course you can use it standalone as you know.  Anyways, it’s just a different workflow.

author: hebakadry
content: Yeah it's got all the basic stuff, but what I like about it, is I can spectrally repair stuff in the same window pane using various degrees of strength/thresholds & intensity & audition it at the same time before you calculate it.  You don’t have to x out to the module to change the intensity for example …with RX you have to do it manually each time on each moment...you can't do like 4 clicks highlighted specifically with their own settings at the same time. Hard to explain but maybe I can make a video for you.  The modules are nowhere as deep as RX like I said, but it’s still super great.

author: hebakadry
content: I wish...that's why I kind of use it in offline mode to see my splices.  Another thing to note (not spectral repair mode) is you can copy the restoration modules like declick-decrackle..even iZotope modules or whatever plugin, save as a snapshot and then paste.

author: Zack Hames
content:
That said - at the level that you, Matt, Cian, Jon, and every other person who’s been on the live, youre not getting completely fucked mixes.

A lot of us still get mixes or recordings that are not fully realized. I know some people in here have said they’d never edit or tune what they were given to mix. There was a time that’s what I spent the majority of my time doing because it was unlistenable until I did. (Happens less and less now 🙂 ) #
I mastered a track recently, the vocal reverb was so whack. They didn’t EQ the reverb at all, it was insanely sibilant just in the reverb, etc. you guys know what I’m talking about. The artist mixed it themself and they’re NOT a mixer, so I kindly prodded and got her to EQ it out. She was thankful and it made it significantly better. 

Also, I did use compression on the bus on that master - but I would never expect a mastering engineer to put that on my mix because I’m compressing my mix already.  

Mixing pop, mixing well produced tracks from seasoned folks who make decisions well before the mixer is involved, is way different than mixing a local bands home recorded ep. Both need totally different perspectives and tools and focuses.

This got derailed…point is, my view on mastering’s role has changed dramatically since listening to LWMR. I hope I never have to “master” my own own mixes again because  I think it’s fundamentally, in some ways, not even truly mastering.

I agree with this approach, and I respect you a lot for not only putting it into practice, but also promoting it to others. 

The thing for me is that I've only been in the technical side of music for a little while, and only really started to go deep with it when the 'rona hit and there was nothing better to do.

author: austenballard

I'm personally inclined to believe you, not because I'm gullible to snake oil (though I'm certainly just as gullible as anyone else when it comes to stuff I don't fully understand) but because I had the privilege of knowing a very intelligent man many years ago who explained to me how electrical currents flow and their impacts on components. author: Ross Fortune
content:
As @Nomograph Mastering said, depends on the material and context.

I spent an afternoon in 2019 comparing options and settled on the following go to options for a Pro Tools environment (would still audition different methods for any exposed/critical parts, but if I need to just slog through and get a big session from one tempo to another, these are where I’ll start):

2 track: audiosuite Waves Soundshifter Parametric (Sync mode)

Vocals: RX standalone 

sample one shots: beat detective on tick based tracks to cut at transients

Perc: elastic audio Rhythmic or Polyphonic 

Bass gtr: waves soundshifter parametric or smooth mode / mono or poly or X Form elastic audio

Most other instruments: waves soundshifter parametric, sync mode

author: spectrummasters
content:
@Nomograph Mastering  right, ruari class finished ! .....ok so, ive a lot of thoughts ...this exercise has made a v big impression on me .
Off top, 

According to RX The mix is at -7.2 LUFS integrated , -6.3 short term, TP -0.1

The artist wants a "bit more low-end " on a fast paced, alt/pop/rock track.
And Imo a little air on top would compliment the mix.
(starting at -7.2 is loud for my experience so its a good challenge and these sort of Lufs are what i want to become v comfortable working at where currently im more comfortable around -9.)

SO i start with your 10 eq points in place , with your q settings and .5 db limits in fabfilter pro q 3  .

Thoughts:

It became clear immediately how powerful to me these q settings and eq points are, with regards to re-shaping the tonal balance.
I cannot recall ever having only used these curves , nor in the absence of any other processing. 
Listening to the impact of 0.1 db up or down in the different areas was remarkable. 

After half an hour id got to something i was v happy with, that appeared "Louder " to me and also.....a bit more lows and a little more open on top. Which id call a success.

Id brought the Pro q output down 0.4db to compensate the gain increase and printed with no limiter.

In RX this printed version showed as -7.2 LUFS integrated , -6.3 short term, TP 0.0 .

Ideally id have not touched this again.....i really liked it. 

Following instructions i then put the L2 Limiter on (modern mode , +0.1 db, TP on and output -0.1) .

Truth be told, once id put the limiter on i wanted to go back into the EQ because i didnt like the sound anymore, i felt the L2 spoilt it.

author: spectrummasters
content: I didnt use any gain up or down of more than 0.3 i believe and the impact of the eq was amazing

author: spectrummasters
content: Im gnna have a jog and thnn will go back into the master again trying a diff limiter and tweaking the eq to compensate for the limiter and see what i get . Overall i didnt get any louder LUFS wise but it imo sounds like something id be excited to send out now and i dont feel like i need to go louder than -7.2 .

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I know there was some chat a while ago about the TDR Simulathe plugin and I'm wondering whether it's worth my investment.  I master records in the independent scene from Wales and usually the bands/labels don't have budget to hire a specialist vinyl cut.  I've never been happy with this and wonder whether this plugin may help optimise for vinyl, the other variable is that most of these records get manufactured via a broker and usually end up being cut at GZ Media in Czechia, I've had good and fairly frequently bad experiences with them so am keen to improve this side of my offering.  If anyone is using Simulathe I would love to get your feedback on it.  I know @hebakadry and @Bonati12461 mentioned it but I think you were using it in conjunction with your actual lathes.

author: spectrummasters
content: @Nomograph Mastering  hi ruairi so I’m on my third listen to “tunnel under ocean boulevard “ and have been really enjoying it . It’s got a vibe of  a david lynch movie about a singer who is the love child of dusty Springfield and Elvis who grew up with Kate bush on tour with Tom waits and roger waters . Anyhoo I digress ! If I may ask as much as poss without asking you to divulge anything compromising about the process : I am fascinated by a few things and wonder what your approach was . In many parts this work feels almost like a  poetry with orchestration and I think has extended parts with little or quite subtle drum parts . I wonder with something like this how do you judge how hard (or not ) to push the overall level (both individual tracks and all together ) as for me I think I tend to judge off what the drums / bass dictates w/regard to level . In this case where drums and bass aren’t really dominating , I’m not sure I’d be as confident in knowing what is the right level . After all there are periods of soft vocal and very gentle lush strings …..these sorts of passages I might get a bit unsure In . I also wondered did you stay in the box for this one ? ….and was this a project for mostly eq more than comp/limiting ? The sound of the record is v expensive and classic imo , do you treat a record like this completely differently with regards to what processes you might use on a different genre (again ITB vs analogue chains ) . Also , I wondered how long did you have to master this ? I’m v interested by engineers abilities not just to perform but to perform to deadlines . It seems this record could go badly wrong if the right choices aren’t made (where a clipped crushed mix could be more forgiving) I wonder how much time you get to review the moves you make on a project like this and if/when you don’t have much time ….do you ever play it safe ?/ make less bold moves in the absence of time to review them ?

author: outofmana
content: what are y’all’s thoughts/best practices for dealing with stuff that is objectively not ready to be mastered? a buddy of mine (talented guy, but massively under developed in his craft) produced/mixed a tune for a new artist and tasked me with mastering it, which I’m happy to do considering it’s relatively low stakes. my buddy is a total pedestrian at engineering and this thing is click/pop/noise city. I’ve taken it about as far as I can with RX but there’s massive sections where the drums are edited so poorly that beyond normal momentary bad cross fade pop noises, the transients are audibly blurred and doing the whoosh thing. do you guys and gals ever just straight up tell a client that it’s not ready or do you do the best you can with the source material? I don’t think he will be able to zoom in enough with critical ears to hear/fix this stuff, but I don’t want to go back to the artist and tell them that I need to charge more to basically crack open the multitrack/do somebody else’s dirty work.

author: spectrummasters

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I take the "whatever we need to do approach", but I've had times where it's totally unreasonable (but on the client side I'd never let them feel that, I remain very encouraging and nice).

But I am in start-up mode and trying to overdeliver. I also use RX a lot and it is generally a massive headache if it keeps going, or the mixes were in rough shape and a lot of RX needed (I find it's generally in this case that there are mix revisions being sent -- the better mixers just have it right and clean from the jump)

If I was in Ruairi's shoes there is no way I could allow what I am currently...but in my case I try to have a convo with them, lovingly, and see why they are sending so many revisions in the first place (generally fear/insecurity and an inability to commit to ideas) and see if we can't have some growth in the long-term mindset too. But very important to feel that one out and know if it's the right situation to challenge a little bit

author: popaganda.
content: A lot of mixers/producers assume the ME just runs the file through a chain and it’s a simple plug and play to swap out the file. If you do rx or stuff like that it’s worth letting them know that it’s actually causing you significantly more work. People just don’t always understand that what you send to the ME is final. I think a one mix rev limit totally makes sense. It’s compassionate but also honors your work and time

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Okay...maybe will get shouted down because this is a gear post...but my bud just let me know Bettermaker put out a new version of their limiter, and saw Dale got some crazy Poland analog limiter thing...setting aside the discussion of if any of these things are "worth it" (obviously it's ridiculous for someone like me to buy a $9k limiter like Dale)...what are the benefits or trade offs of analog limiters and maybe these in particular? Has anyone used them? Do they open any doors that digital just doesn't?

( For instance, I love the sound of tubes in my MP, and while I very much think it's a color and not what everything needs, it does definitely do an amazing thing when it's right)

@Nomograph Mastering @Rollmottle  and anyone else looking to share thoughts I'd be interested...the clipping functionality/color and plug-in recall makes the creative possibilities of the Bettermaker sorta interesting...I've been looking for a way to get maybe a little "analog" love on some stuff but without hitting tubes and giving too much color.

https://www.bettermaker.com/mastering-limiter-2-0
https://www.hum-audio.com/laal-mastering-limiter/

No one is an analog anything away from being good at mastering, but was just curious if anyone has thoughts on the trade-offs

author: Rollmottle
content: I have no experience with the Bettermaker. I'd be hard-pressed to believe it can outperform a digital limiter in terms of transparency. The LAAL seems interesting, but not something I'd be dropping $9K on. The Bettermaker acts like a plugin, so why not just use a plugin.

author: masteredbyjack
content: I do not. Just got my MP and in the box (which of course has saturation options) but honestly I was just sorta curious about the limiters…I’m very very rarely saturating anything. Mostly just EQ and limiter, spectre isn’t bad for a light touch

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Cool! Honestly slightly hesitant to branch out, at the stage I’m at I’m still building rock solid fundamentals, but when it’s right I’ll give it a go

I don’t doubt some saturation could help sometimes, but it’s still more my EQ and limiting skills that are making the biggest difference you know? I’ve found the most growth in very much restricting my options and just focusing on the very bottom level stuff (and the music sounds legit better because of it)

author: Rollmottle
content: big question...i broadly think about the digital EQ as "corrective," as in framing the song to where i think it needs to sit, not necessarily technical correction. (the RX stage is where that happens). sometimes that's the end of it if the mix is good enough. but sometimes there's more to be had and that's typically when i go analog. not that i don't think digital couldn't also get me there, but that the analog does it in a way i find more pleasing and faster. i probably have the luxury of more time than Ruairi does per project and if my circumstances changed, my approach might change. in broad strokes, that's how my brain thinks about it.

author: Rollmottle
content: there's an insane thread in the mastering forum on GS about people's plugin chains. color EQ, color comp, clean EQ,  clean comp, colorizer, saturator, multibandwhatever, etc and multiples of each. it is just anathema to how i think about the world and blows my mind that people are burdening themselves with such complexity.

author: Bryan DiMaio

I don't care about what settings or gear people use

doesn't mean it's not fun to look at cool studios, but Ruairi could probably master a track with a potato and a stock eq and it would come out great

I'm all about using ears, doing tests like what I've done this morning, but having some technical explanation for stuff such as why oversampling is even in an option in Pro-DS and Pro-C and when people are using it can help guide the ears some more as you know what to listen for.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Then, in various orders you’ll have automatic gain control (very long slow dynamic control), multiband compression, EQ and auto EQ (that moves), stereo widening, phase rotation (a deep topic on it’s own), bass enhancement, clippers, limiters etc etc

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Only takes a second to RX 4824 to 4416 and then I just QC the 4416

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: So just give them everything they could need. My rate is already higher than average so I don't have any reason to skimp on a few versions if they don't take me any extra time. Literally just the time it takes to create a folder called 4416 and 4424. RX is already open anyway

author: masteredbyjack
content:
When you are referring to this, do you QC just the literal downsample?

In my workflow I QC on import…so I’d catch any odd stuff, clicks, whatever (in all the alts too). Then of course the finals that go out, the highest res render (changes depending on project like you stated).

But just a downsample to 4416 (or whatever) you even QC? What could go wrong there? (I’ve tested RX pretty extensively and I’ve never seen it add an error just downsampling minus a potential over here or there depending…I do account for potential overs from the downsampling and make sure there aren’t any…etc)

Open to being wrong about this, but haven’t had any problems so far (caveat with my experience is minimal compared to you and Gerhard, Rollmottle, etc)

author: Edsel Holden
content: There is not much that ruins the groove and vibe of a great song for me more than a vocal that is EXTREMELY loud and upfront and disconnected from the music. In instances where it is not possible to have the mixer tuck the vocal down for me, does anyone here have any workflows that they like for helping connect and vocal to the song at the mastering stage ? I have tried izotope rebalance once or twice with mild success. Sometimes some mid side tomfoolery can help. But figured I’d ask the the hive kind. Tons of love to everyone on this lovely Friday

author: Rollmottle
content: Nothing you probably haven’t tried or thought of. Simply pulling down the center (or raising the sides) can help. I use Equilibrium for this.  Izotope rebalance for a db or so. EQ obviously. Really extreme cases might call for mid side compression fuckery but I’d first probably accept the mix has a loud vocal before going down that path.

author: Edsel Holden
content: Anyone here ever edit down a few true peak samples in RX (just moving down the samples that are offending) when a master is great but just has a few pesky true peak overs but feels great otherwise? I just started doing this and i like it.. good weekend to us all ❤️

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Yeah occasionally I have done this, mostly because I don’t like true peak limiting (in my admittedly limited experience so far), which occasionally will allow some bigger true peaks through

Ruairi much more an authority on this than me, but I also find it satisfying when it says 0 exactly

Also if I go analog I upsample so that usually will stop there from being true peaks of much note unless its ultra hot

I am looking into how to write a sound flow script or something in RX to be a “limiter” in this sense, in that it could limit digital peaks (or true peaks) totally transparently by just turning down samples to a given value…just a curiosity for now

author: Nomograph Mastering
