author: masteredbyjack
content:
Yep same session! Wavelab for me, montage. Some caveats apply, like if you are doing a seamless transition I find it useful to print to a new montage file to avoid any chance of an odd click or pop across the track transition, the new montage print seems to solve that (obviously always have to QC) but that's the only time I do that

Also have to caveat this with I am quite new, but I've done quite a few album/EP projects and the spacing in the same file seems very much the right move for me (my plugin use is pretty minimal so rendering the files isn't much of a lift on the back end when it's ready to go)

And circling back to not having the tracklist -- very common for me, not a big deal, your workflow should have a way to handle it without it being a problem in today's day and age. But I will certainly go back and look at spacing/volume in the intro/outros for sure with the tracklist. Have had projects go out and they didn't provide a tracklist, last second decision and it was totally fine

author: Edsel Holden
content: I usually do it all in the one Montage in wavelab, but I know Nathan D at The Hit Lab runs a separate montage just for sequencing. He told me that it's so that sequencing changes can render in an instant and can be opened on any rig without plugin worrys. Smart worlfow for the volume they do there for sure.

author: Maxim
content:
I’m not a mastering engineer but my first move would be trying to highlight the hihat in RX with the brush tool and gaining it down + maybe using some spectral repair. 

If that doesn’t work I’d probably try isolating the hi hat on a seperate track (RX music rebalance to get drums) and only for those offensive sections automate a sidechain that ducks the hihat signal from the mix with something like Soothe.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I haven’t used the RX monitor feature. Do you make the moves in RX and hear the playback from your DAW or how does that work?

author: Adam Thein
content: It's a plugin you can drop into your DAW on any channel - if I'm working on a vocal later on in the mix, I can plop the RX monitor at the first insert, then set your Driver Type to "RX Monitor" in the Audio settings in RX, and it will pipe the output of RX directly to the plugin in your DAW, allowing you to monitor RX through whatever chain you are processing with.

author: Reedy
content: My life circumstances have changed, so my reaction to that mess was basically to stop mixing and go fulltime on this business idea I've been sitting on for a while. Was getting fed up of mixing records I didn't like so my main thing now is to only mix records I like and probably going forward only mix records for people going on my label. Means I can be really selective which works better for me because I've been through so many shit situations in the last 2 years. (This story is one of many). Through everything, I've learned that I care far too much about pleasing the artist and I jumped through way too many hoops to do so. In future, I will give less of a shit. Which sounds like a terrible idea, but really I'm just trying to dial back my obsessive behaviour. In terms of technicals, I learned nothing in the situation, artist could hear something that fucked everything up for them, I could hear nothing, none of my peers could hear what the artist was talking about either. Was only the mastering chain, as the mix was fine. I turned off every plugin individually to get at the issue and it remained. I think it was a combination of things, but I've never had anyone pinpoint the issue before and admittedly I mostly use the same combination of plugins for my mastering jobs (for functionality reasons, not because this specific combination of plugins make the records 'sound' better).

author: Adam Thein
content:
I’ll take a stab, I’m sure others can chime in to add more to this:

Mastering is the final step in record making - typically with an engineer who has yet to hear the song in its final form.

The mastering stage is often where a track is set to its final level, quality controlled for technical issues (unintentional noise), and often subjectively sweetened or tonally shifted based on the taste of the engineer.

The actual processing involved can vary widely but often engineers are relying on EQ and limiting most prominently, although they may also reach for non linear processors such as compression, saturation, and other coloring tools.

content:
......fine folks of the mastering echelons.....i wonder your experiences/impressions on something..
I find more frequently now that the simple act of engaging the limiter on a mix before even any gaining...subtly but profoundly impacts the stereo image and depth of the mix to such an extent that i feel im immediately in a disadvantageous starting point from there on. I find this with Pro L, Izotope Vintage Limiter , Maximiser (in diff modes) and Standard Clip. 
I wonder is tis an experience others here have encountered and if so, how did you mitigate ?

author: spectrummasters
content:
Sorry I may not have articulated that to well , 

Eg . Last night I had a really great  mix to master for someone . Really open warm and great balance , v similar to love galore by Travis scott and sza. I couldn’t help but feel the act of engaging any plug ins , but especially any of my limiters immediately distorted the sense of width  and depth and where objects in the mix were placed. I’ve sensed this a couple of times before  . I sat there for about half an hour going between dual mono and stereo instances of all my limiting  plug ins ….and then sitting there going between different phase modes on my eq and it seemed none of them preserved the dimensions of the mix

author: Rob Domos
content:
Best practices question: 

I sent out a bunch of finished, approved, dithered mixes to a client and then they told me the song order sequence and wanted me to tighten up the transitions, so I loaded those dithered mixes up and trimmed tops and tails. I imagine since I didn’t add any processing (other than one imperceptible fade) and I already randomized the bottom bit in the previous project that I should be good to export and ship as is, but are there any reasons why it would have been functionally better to have done tops and tails on the undithered file and applied dithering afterwards?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Your edited fades are now 32 or 64 float in the DAW and “should” be dithered again to minimize distortion when you truncate to 16 or 24 bit

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my understanding and tests, yes if it is imported in a DAW and changed at all, we are now in 32 or 64 bit land. Will you hear this difference? Most likely no like Ruairi said, it would have to be a very specific case.

Over here I always dither after export in RX, so it solves that issue. And for an album I’ll print the whole thing to a separate montage so if it’s just spacing or whatever that needs to change, it’s easy enough and no re-rendering of plugins is necessary (and Wavelab seems to handle seamless transitions better this way)

I’ve seen a fair amount of non-limited mixes that I find out are truncated to 24 bit depth — any over zeros that a limiter was catching go to zero — and even then it usually doesn’t really sound horrible since it’s often a very fast transient peak. But something to be aware of

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I would not dither of if I pulled into float and did not do a level change

author: aidanthillmann
content:
Hi, I’m not a mastering engineer but I did a sort of mastering experiment recently:

I was watching the Mix with the Masters videos with Randy Merrill and Idania Valencia, and I noticed that they were using plain old input gain before their limiter to push it instead of increasing the threshold of the limiter itself, so their limiter thresholds/gains were at 0. I thought maybe they knew something I didn’t.

So I tried it. I put a gain plugin before my limiter and pushed the limiter with it. The results? It sounds awful. All the punch and width is gone. Change back to using the limiter’s threshold, sounds great.

Any technical reason for this? I was using the Kilohearts Gain plugin in to Ozone Maximizer, but I would be hard pressed if it was one of those plugins at fault. Maybe the threshold of the limiter has an internal signal flow that changes its behavior as opposed to gain coming in to it or something? Maybe this workflow makes better sense in Sequoia for the Sterling engineers for some reason?

author: masteredbyjack
content: I actually believe @cian riordan mentioned here before that there IS something different about how the Ozone maximizer reacts to pushing gain into it with threshold at 0 vs using the input gain. For my workflow, when I use it I'm pushing into it with the input gain, so I'd have to do some tests. But for other limiters (limitless, Pro L2), I haven't noticed a big difference between what you're suggesting -- very open to being wrong about that though!

author: aidanthillmann
content: @masteredbyjack I’ll try it with Pro L and see if it does the same thing, if not then it could just be an Ozone thing

author: wald
content: So Im finishing a track that Ive produced (that will also end up being the master…its the world I live in🙈) The reference going in was a modern ‘tate mcrae’ ish vibe aka loud AF. My approach was to build that density up from scratch, but to keep the 2bus streamlined. Set the vocal at the absolute level it needed to be and built rest of mix around that. 2 bus = Ozone maximizer doing -2.8 db. SO chuffed, everyone super happy. V1 signoff vibes etc. Come print and prep day, I pull up WLM to check levels etc and see Ive got 4.6 db true peak overshoot that ozone let through. (Basically every snare hit) Properly painted myself into a corner…Ive got 1 db at most to turn down before artist becomes bummed. True peak limiting =really kills the vibe. Actually, any move to mitigate the overshoot makes it sound contrived/distorted and less open than the 4db true peak. So my Question- what am I risking downstream if I keep as is?

author: wald
content: I have, going up to about 1.5 db kinda stay’s transparent, but does almost nothing for the TP. However, Pro L after ozone, oversampled, does catch and reduce it within 1.5 db over (which is kinda par for the course with that stuff I guess) . There is a bit of a price to pay in that it sounds less natural 🤷🏼‍♂️ Hence the Q about severity of the issue.

author: nachomaquieira
content:
Hey folks! I always read and learn from the great stuff you share around here, and I thought it'd be cool to share something out of the ordinary that I did today for this particular situation. I was tasked with mastering a r&b/pop song with a kick and 808 really upfront, but they weren't cutting through or punching in the low/mids due to lack of EQ on the kick and saturation on the 808. (And no time to make corrections!)

To fill in what was missing, I tried a few things, but what worked best for me to address both issues was sending it to a parallel devil-loc (which is killer for adding low-mids and saturation), and using the Ozone imager to make it only sound from 500Hz downwards and make it mono. Luckily, they sent me the music and the lead vocals separately, so I was able to do this without compromising the vocal color. For this particular situation, it worked beautifully. Cheers!

author: Deleted User
content:
This is slightly related but my recent discovery is that subtle differences don’t matter until it matters to me. And I have to be clear and intentional to myself about what is the deficit that I’m trying to fill. This informs the gear choices. Until then, subtle differences are no differences to me - therefore no need to spend ANY money on it. And anything beyond this much of a difference is a waste of brain power. 

But I don’t live in the world of extra 2% (mastering). 

Simplifying everything and reassessing it every now and then works the best for how my brain works. Use the same thing over and over, and it teaches me how to do more with it. I think it is the same idea as Jon Casteli’s “I only use 10 plugins”

author: Nick Stetina
content:
+ @Rollmottle , you know what, poor word choice on my part by saying “undoing”, haha. What I really meant was in the event of a revision request. 

For example, I worked on a song this week with a jazz quartet instrumentation and a singer with a bit of a lisp. Super dynamic mix, the upright bass had a lot of wild moments that needed to be reigned in. Always gonna follow my gut on the to first pass, but also recognize the singer’s potential sensitivity to how their lisp comes across on the recording. I just opted to focus on the instrumentals on the first pass in RX, save the file, duplicate it, then work from that and focus on vocals. They approved on the first pass, but if I had to go back to the drawing board on the vocals, for example, I did not want to have to go through every note plucked on the upright bass again and would be thankful to have that ‘RX_INST’ file on hand.

Which I guess brings up another workflow question: are you splitting focus when in RX and doing multiple passes, or just play through once addressing whatever it is you hear as you go?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I’m sure you know this, but for those not in on the RX train, you can just save it as an RXdoc, it will keep your undo history. Would that eliminate the need for the multiple files?

But you have to be careful what order you do things in…if you want to get back to a specific step you undo all the ones before that

author: masteredbyjack

author: Rollmottle
content: it keeps the undo history without saving an RXdoc if you open RX and have the file still in a tab. it does not do that if you just open a new file.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Does anyone use Meterplugs’ Perception plugin to level match unprocessed mixes to mastered mixes? I’ve stopped using it as it doesn’t seem to work with Apple Silicon, and i’ve found it quite nice without it. I trust my own perception more, make better moves and go with what feels right. If something feels wrong i’ll just level match before and after using Metric A/B.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I don't use that plugin -- but I absolutely will master things loudness matched to the REF just using Wavelab. And certainly listen to level matched often (I like Loudness Penalty Studio for something outside the DAW that's easy). Once I get it to the volume of the REF I'll just use the linked limiting input/output to keep it at the level of the REF to understand if what I'm adding in level and processing is making it better. Of course not on everything, but with stuff that's really hot already I find it very useful! To be sure that we are making it better not just louder, louder is usually quite easy (but can often translate quieter)

And I'll turn in things quieter if I think it's better too. Rarely but I certainly have done it with a short note like @Nomograph Mastering mentioned before "thought x thing that was awesome about this felt better at this density"

author: Eric Martin
content:
I made the move for mastering and it makes my brain work a little different because it’s the only time I use WaveLab, that being said.

I wouldn’t (if I could go back) switch unless you were driving daily in mastering, that DAW has a steep learning curve.

Mastering generally has multiple steps in multiple softwares to make sure that you’re controlling the quality of product that you’re sending out as finished, it’s kinda hard to get away from that part. I still open files in multiple softwares to finish work using WaveLab primarily because of RX and file up-loaders.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Hi Eric, I do a lot of mastering for the scene I'm from and always liked the two stage process of doing all my processing in Pro Tools and then assembling CD's in a montage in Hofa.  The problem is switching files and correcting fades or addtional editing. ideally I'd like all of it to be doable in Pro Tools with object based editing but that seems a long way off.  I used DSP Quattro many years ago and that was good but the support sort of died out, I know it's possible in Reaper but the curve of making it behave the way i want it to is too steep.  RX gets used mainly before Pro Tools if i hear anything that needs attention.

I’m also not mastering day in day out, I used to, but now I’m tracking more drums, and mostly just doing construction 🤣

author: miguel @ knurlmastering
content: I still think that linear phase EQing is very program-dependent, more than anything else. On the Weiss EQ1, I use both standard and linear phase modes; most of the time, one just works better than the other and is usually noticeable. It’s one of those things that I’ve stopped trying to intellectualize and just go with what sounds best on a per-case basis. It’s very hard to specify exact scenarios where one will always be better than the other, at least for music production! So while in theory one might be better than the other for a specific task, not all music handles EQing the same way.

author: Nick Stetina

I mastered a single for a young band, its their first time hiring a dedicated mastering engineer. The singer sent over a revision request with a screenshot of an EQ with boosts and cuts ranging from +/- 3-5db in various places using headphones for review (not sure what model). I checked out the requests this morning and it truly feels like we’re EQing for this guys specific headphones, the master really suffers from it, imo.

How would you toe the line on this one from the low friction, “how high?” attitude on one end of the spectrum to opening up a dialogue about “rather than specific EQ points, can you describe what it is you’re trying to achieve from each of these? Can you share if there are any references your A/Bing agains that may be insightful?”

author: Soundswithsammy
content: Hey everybody! A question about mastering for Vinyl? Should 808 based hiphop be handled any differently (dithering or otherwise) when mastering for Vinyl? Would the grooves handle the 808s I add to them, as long as the digital master is good?

author: Berlin
content: It's not how deep your low end is, but how in phase it is down there with those 808s on vinyl. I would consult with your cutting engineer, but they likely have an elliptical EQ in their mastering chain to clean up out of phase sub frequencies - common practice. That being said, if your 808s are panned or have alot of stereo/out of phase information, the result of the cut will likely differ from your digital master. - Again, I'd talk it through with your cutting engineer, if you can! a real convo if you can and not just going by a one-size-fits-all spec sheet from a manufacturer.

author: Berlin
content: Regarding dither, I wouldn't SRC and just send the highest quality available to you - same resolution as the mixes - since it's going to analog, but that's me!

author: Nicky Howard
content:
I completely agree with you that it would be impossible to give feedback on all the different artifacts encountered.

This is more specific. There must be a cause—something like a common vocal plugin or interface that would at least be helpful to advise clients that it could create this. Prevention rather than the cure.

It's like a periodic set of hairline clicks after each phrase. I'm hearing it much more regularly, which is why I wondered if anyone else had encountered it.

I started mastering before RX, and it's now a fully integrated part of the process. Some people certainly choose not to take this route, which is cool if it works for them. 👍

The dreaded mic'd-up mouse click!

This feels more like a plug-in firing in a few faint clicks when the vocal drops enough in level, periodically in time, almost clock-related.

Maybe it's just something that's  destined for eternal RXing!

- Asking for multiple verison so they can choose, vs commiting to a destination and iterating if necessary

- Very detailed EQ instructions that often change a specific thing but harm the whole master

author: masteredbyjack
content:
The only time I specifically avoid true peak (I don’t think I’ve ever actually preferred true peak limiting) is on an open ballad type song, pianos in the open and it’s still getting limited, etc.

Usually it’s no issue. But I will draw down any very big ones, just to be sure

Best thing to do though is just make the actual codecs in RX or something — you can listen to them and actually check them (Ruairi posted stuff about this awhile back but I’m not sure what you would search to find it). Thus no guess work.

@Rollmottle with great tips no surprise

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Same. Turns out just using our ears is best overall. I think the only thing that I find useful is if there is an album where we are trying to maximize streaming translation, being able to see the integrated scores of all the tracks at the end within the software can help. Of course only after deciding based on listening.

Or if there's a track where I'm adjusting an intro level, you can see how far you can go before the integrated score gets hit, basically like a manual version of the RX module (which I haven't heard sound good yet, but the principle is interesting to understand)

author: Rollmottle
content:
I guess I do that too but sub a clipper for a one of your limiters. I don’t really think of that as spreading the load in the way it’s talked about in these threads. I think of that as solving a problem. 

The thrust of the idea that seems to be selling in these threads is that it’s always better to process gently on two than it is to do so “aggressively” on one. While that may be right for specific problems, it seems to be the folk wisdom for EQ and compression over there. Like, if you need to cut 2db at 5k, just cut it with one EQ, not two.

author: Berlin
content: I’m not sure the genesis of that kind of thinking, but many years ago when I was beginning, I made my way into it for a short while. author: mariano
content:
Hey everyone, hope you're all doing well.

I have a question. I’ve been learning a lot about mixing and mastering over the years, and everywhere I look stresses the importance of keeping the low end centred and being cautious with the sides.

Today, I was analysing a track of mine that just got mastered by a highly skilled and popular UK engineer. I noticed the low end seemed quite wide, with a lot of information on the sides. While it sounds pleasant, I also picked up some non-audible low frequencies in the sides (see the screenshot, red is side signal) , and ofc the waveform looked a bit offset...

I understand this could come from certain production plugins or DSP processing, but I’m wondering - shouldn’t this be addressed in the mastering stage? I know it's not too difficult to fix, but I’d love to hear your thoughts on it.

Thanks so much! x x

author: flyboystudio
content:
Hey all, first of all just want to say how stoked I am to have found this community! Discovered the LWMR podcasts a few months back and have truly loved listening and learning. 

I’ve had a note back from a ME that I’ve used a few times via an artist I work with, asking to send an unlimited version of the final mix. 
Final mix had the limiter off but I mixed into standard clip doing a couple db of soft clipping here and there, pretty minimal, so left that on. 

Mix bus was: SSL G Comp - Maag EQ - Oxford Inflator - Standard Clip (Soft Clip Pro, 5% Saturation, 8 x oversampling). All very light touches along the way. 

Sent loud mix to A&R and artist (less than 2db reduction on limiter) but they also approved the pre master in this instance i.e with mix bus on but limiter off. 

Although the ME has the approved mix already, I’m thinking of sending a version without any clipping and asking to hear 2 versions…

Any thoughts welcomed!

Hey folks, first off just wanted to say I’m extremely grateful for stumbling across this group via LWMR - I’ve just been reading through the groups soaking up all the epic conversations, recommendations and knowledge that’s currently being shared!

I’ve recently been getting some feedback on mix + masters and recurrence has been that chorus’ and bigger sections of songs need more stereo width. There is major panning already happening within these tracks… so I’ve been trialing out imaging tools such as S1 imager, Ozone Imager, T-racks imager, Microshift & Doubler. I’m aware it’s important to be cautious with these plug-ins as they can introduce phasing issues. I’m also finding the stereo sound these plug ins are producing sounds - fake, thin, untasteful and feels as thought is alters the song in negative way. 

At times I thought maybe I’m need more instrumentation within these arrangement to play with panning - but I hear absolutely gorgeous tracks that are simply a vocal and an acoustic guitar that have such a rich deep stereo field (almost as if there were 2 acoustic gtr’s) 

I’ve been starting to play with M/S eq and have been having some small wins - but would appreciate and thoughts, views, opinions or direction!

Thanks team 🙏🏼

author: Eric Martin
content:
I think the cutting engineers job has to turn it down so that the cutting head doesn’t jump, but from my understand just turning down a crazy limited digital mastering is going to result in a bad sounding vinyl, I could be way off, but a cutting/mastering engineer that I work with essentially told me the best practice prep is to EQ and level for a master but don’t limit or compress if the mixes were already compressed sounding, the end result vinyl will sound better that way.

I recently did exactly this and mastered a record essentially to -16 doing the EQ that made things sound right but didn’t limit at all because it didn’t need it, and the cutting engineer will do the transfer.

author: Paris Lee
content:
@Stefan 
I don’t audition different converters on every track. That would drive me insane. 
For an album that would be more of a thing…but I’ll be honest I’ll just use one converter for a while across some projects and then I’ll switch to the other one arbitrarily for a while…

(I have a Crane Song Interstellar and a Lavry Savitr
Both great All Rounders that have proven legacies  and hard to get a bad sound out of…)

I’m not a big believer that the converter is the ‘barrier’ to delivering your best work. If you’re in a room where you’re hearing what’s happening clearly, you can work. Now we all have our preferences on that ‘last 5 percent’ of sonics, which influences your decision, but if I can hear the eq and get a cohesive tight image and strong center, it doesn’t matter, I’m fine. All of that is Much more important. 

These converters are all so fucking good now. I think 15 years ago which one you had was more of a heated discussion. 

Just don’t feel the need to go off the reservation on the ones you’ve seen in the top guys racks over the years, and…DONT BUT SOME VINTAGE THING THAT COULD BREAK ON YOU!!! Get something new that’s supported. 

Maybe I over answered haha. Coffee ya know

author: Paris Lee
content: ‘Riding the distortion’ is such an important thing- when the timing of the distortion is locked within the ‘groove of the record’ then it is much less noticeable and poking out to our ears and you can go a little harder. Delta plugins can be very beneficial- this goes for clipping and de essing also. Listen to the ‘delta’ (can be annoying and not so great for your hearing so don’t do it a long time) and get your distortion in rhythm with the record. I guess the best way to describe that is when you get that sort of wobble where you can’t hear everything (duh you’re hearing only the added distortion) but the gaps fill in in your mind and you can follow the timing- then you’ll be happy with the result plus the trade offs induced.

author: conordalton
content: Has anyone ever experimented with automating dither to only turn on during the quiet sections (where it’s most needed) and off during the loud sections?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Assuming 16 bit dither down at something like -90 dBFS what is the expected outcome when turning it off during loud (touching 0dBFS) sections?

author: conordalton
content:
The though process goes like this: 

In loud passages, the signal is already masking the quantization distortion well so adding noise to the signal here in the form of dither might not be necessary

In quiet or fading parts, quantization distortion becomes more audible because the signal no longer masks it.

Dither decorrelates the quantization error from the signal so that it becomes random noise instead of harmonic distortion.

When the distortion is already inaudible because of masking, dithering doesn’t add a practical audible benefit but it just adds noise.

The goal is potentially reducing noise in the signal, for a (slightly) clearer sound

I haven't experimented with this myself yet, but i am curious if anyone had researched it a bit or heard of this technique before?

author: conordalton
content:
I feel like I can hear a difference between different dither types. So if I can hear the difference between different dither types then I can hear the dither or at least the effect of the dither on the song (sometimes) 

The question is if the quantization distortion is more or less audible than the dither noise at loud sections of the song, and if the quantization distortion is less audible than the dither then it makes a case for automating the dither to when it’s actually necessary (the quiet sections of the song)

But that’s at the limit of my understanding and knowledge on the subject so I welcome your thoughts and experience about it

author: Rollmottle
content: Hard to imagine dither being on or off in certain sections of a song making or breaking the record. It's an easy enough experiment to run though.

author: conordalton
content: I’m not sure how to scientifically test which is more audible, quantization distortion (on loud sections) or dither noise (on loud sections), but maybe someone smarter than me can shed some light on it or point me in the right direction

author: conordalton
content:
Yeah: I remember that I used the same dither for years and years, it lived on my output, and I didn’t care to test others because “dither is dither, who cares” but then I was recommended airwindows “notjustanotherdither” plugin and did a blind A/B test and could pick out my standard dither compared to the airwindows one 10/10 times, especially because the other one had lived on my chain for so long I had become so accustomed to hearing its kind of fuzzy tone compared to the noise shaped dither of airwindows

Granted I couldn’t pick out differences on a bunch of different dithers but on this one particular occasion the difference was very clear as I had a lot of exposure to one sound before making the switch

author: Rollmottle
content: Maybe I don't understand what you're trying to do, but why isn't it as simple as printing a file with a loud and quiet section with the dither automated as you've specified? Two files: one is dithered normally. The other is dithered, but the dither is automated out at the loud section. Isn't that the test?

author: masteredbyjack
content: So the true peaks will be the same in a 32bit file or 24 or 16, you can just look in RX or whatever, 32bit just allows headroom for dbfs over zero

author: masteredbyjack
content: But if you’re using a limiter, then the 32bit print or the 24/16dithered file is going to have the same TP. The TP is not affected by the bit depth, as it is a measure of the recreated waveform between the digital samples

Lately I’ve gotten a hold of TDR elliptical and TDR ultrasonic and find both of them very good additions 
‘Traditional Disc Mastering’ preset is solid starting point on beat oriented music. 

My new export scheme in Reaper involves upsampling the file to 96k mastering there. And using chain upsampling post converter at 192 and leaving oversampling off plugins whenever possible…placing ultrasonic after the last limiter seems to be  helpful but also something probably to be cautious with fussing too much around with other than turn if on and see if it’s better, has extra features that are above my pay grade (nyquist hard limit, dynamic gating…) 

I export out at 44/48 64 bit and get that out of the way and the chain OS still stays at 192. 

Db power amp to 24 bit triangle dither. 

Voxengo R8brain in Reaper, to me, is pretty damn good

author: BananErMat42
content: Q: if you tamper with a mastered track because there was a simple mistake made you can easily fix yourself (lets say there was too much silence at the start which messed up the flow from the previous track), you dont do anything but cut some of the silence and re-bounce (no dithering, no normalization, peaks are all the same, file format is identical), and your label provides the ISRC. What could go wrong? I asked on a different mastering page and was overwhelmed by engineers who seemed to think it was sacrilegious of me to even suggest such a thing. Did they have a point?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Depends how you do it — if you fade in a DAW the file will go up to 32bit probably, so that’s something to know. And you’d have to export or dither down to a releasable bit depth (see above discussion on dither a bit ago). Certainly not sacrilege though.

The way you describe their response makes it seem ridiculous to me

If you are asking if as a mastering engineer I would ever advise someone I shipped a master to that they do such a thing on their end, I would say no, simply since I cannot put my stamp on it that it’s been done correctly. I’d do it and provide the file (maybe this is what they meant)

But what happens when files are out of our hands is not in our control

author: BananErMat42

I mean ive made bootleg edits and remixes out of 2-tracks for 15 years and never had an issue with how my bounces sound, so i figured It’d be fine to do a quick DIY as the label were being a bit iffy about it, saying they didn’t have the budget for a recall from the ME. author: Nick Stetina
content:
I had a project with pretty strident cymbals recently. Each cymbal with their own distinctly harsh, static frequency, and frequent but momentary overtones (pretty scathing, think cheap SDC). 

I’m curious what everyone’s workflow/approach may be in a situation like this knowing as the drummer changes from hats to ride, crash, etc. through a song that the treatment to address it changes…are you going into RX tedium? Automation wormhole?

I’ve largely used RX for quicker, more momentary processing so the idea of selecting 10.4kHz across an entire chorus, for example, and attenuating that is somewhat foreign to me (and probably hard to replicate if faced with a file swap), but curious anyone finds themselves processing in RX like that?

author: Nick Stetina

author: Paris Lee
content:
Rx De click is pretty bad in reaper when you’re splitting clips and put it on high. Reaper can crap the audio when it hits that section (sometimes not but it’s pretty fuckin unpleasant to listen to 
So yeah you apply FX to take on that section, it will then stack the second waveform below the first, and you make the bounced one active. Make sure to go into your reaper preferences and set apply fx, glue, etc…to 64 bit…but no 32 won’t kill you)

author: Paris Lee
content:
I got myself, in not  a catastrophic bind,  but a situation that is unfortunately adding more stress to my client than need be- in a very high stakes situation where I have to perform and will be rewarded with a whole host of new opportunities if I do. 

Was approached for a commercial jingle master (and as always, asked exactly when you need this, and adjusted my schedule accordingly with the appropriate wiggle room for anything that comes up. 

Well…shit came up…and it’s my making 

I Was sent the WAV a week ago (one song), told them I’d get to it in a week, and it’s due on Friday. 

Get to the computer today, and alas, it’s a compressed file masquerading as a wav. 

Now, the exec producer behind the song is occupying the studio-with an artist who DOES NOT get interrupted for any reason *whatsoever* 

so they’re going to get me the file as soon as they can, but it’s gonna cut much closer than I wanted it to. 

I converted it to wav and have the master basically where i want it when it comes in.

Totally on me. Could have all been avoided if I just looked at it in RX before tucking it away in the queue.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
(copy/paste)

Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively). a dB or two of clipping will help the limiter work less.

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Then dial the Gain on Pro-L to give you the limiting and level you want

Am I missing something ?

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
My last update on this - How the first go went.

I ended up tweaking things throughout the sesh, and kept a lot of what was said here in mind as I navigated settings and mindsets.

These plugins will all be in a template inactive, but it helps me account for a lot of possible scenarios I could come across and how I'd approach it.

Here are the strokes I ended up doing for this test:

1. I did end up using RX and Soothe for this, since the test was a one take with many flaws.
2. MB did heavy lifting for control
3. I did a smiley face EQ on it and it felt appropriate, but also because of the lack of mixing on the raw one-take. 
4. ShadowHills 0.5-1.5dB on optical and discrete rebalanced at different levels felt like it added a sense of dimension that wasn't there.
5. Studer - Added, but again keeping in mind that it added characteristics I need to be careful putting onto a refined mix. This gave it some harmonic life it was missing.
6. Pro-DS - made some horrendous high end sound more bearable.
7. Pro-Q3 - some last lil notches for problem frequencies, especially up high and unpleasant.
8. Oxford Limiter - barely dancing thresh, slower attack, fast rls, inflator 42%, cus I'm spicy.

-

If anyone reads this and has comments or statements about any of this, please let me know if you'd like to give thoughts here, or if you'd like me to send you the before and after to gauge my decisions relative to your taste, based on the decisions I made for this file.

author: aliberger
content: i guess i'm concerned about dithering twice and wondering if it makes more sense to re-export at 32-bit and use that as the basis for the cd and tape versions

author: Rob Domos
content: “Double Dither” isn’t really a concern, because dithering is less about adding some noise and more about randomizing the bottom two bits. If they’ve already been randomized, randomizing them again shouldn’t really make any real difference. Its not like the dither would get louder

author: aliberger
content: sweet, thank you, especially for describing dither in that way cause that really made something click for me

author: aliberger
content: and then i SRC'd and dithered that one and the 24 bit master each down to 16/44

author: Berlin
content:
If you want you can implement 2x oversampling to help mitigate ISP a little, but if you wanted a little more control, you can upsample and work at that high sample rate. Export at that higher sample rate, and 32bit float.

SRC and Dither using RX for your various formats.

Reassemble in your DAW for each program. i.e. Main Master, DDP, or Vinyl Premaster.

Find a workflow that works for
you.

Lots of folks don’t worry about these things and just export, listen and party. 🎉

author: James Cronier
content:
There’s a lot of tweak-ability with Standard Clip’s oversampling and filter. Personally, I’d get my ears familiar with the oversampling amounts and the non-over sampled setting in the plugin. Some of those settings are pretty hard to differentiate, but some have clear differences. The clipping will sound different.

Then I’d play with default linear phase vs minimum phase oversampling filter. That difference is readily apparent to my ears. 

The slope and frequency of the filters have an incredible amount of variability. There are a staggering amount of possible settings. I can’t offer much on the sound of those changes. Maybe others can offer more insight.

author: James Cronier
content: It can be hard to A/B these ~within~ the plugin. The audio stops and takes a while to back kick in. I’d recommend duplicating your master bus/track and shuffle the mutes over a short loop of material. That should allow you to hone in on the differences.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
Additionally, I know some artists love to comp thoroughly after the fact but it could be helpful (and idk your current workflow so you may already do this) to go one of two routes:
1. color code any specific takes that may be keepers outright
2. try to be as intentional as possible while tracking so you're building the comp as you go and you know when you get "the take"

Most of the vocals I track are comped, edited, and aligned on the fly while tracking. It took me years of practice to be able to do all that while still paying attention to the current take that's being sung but I find artists love the speed they can see their song come together

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: But it results in something that ends up very close to what the final will be (maybe an after the fact comp here or there, and some corrective tuning if need be with Melodyne), right at the end of the vocalist's last take

author: Beck Nebel
content: I’m generally trying to do a quick comp and tune after last take - set a timer for 10-15 minutes, give them a break
